summary: Lift the gallbladder wall to create a knuckle and approach across, not into, the tissue. Keep instrument angled upward to avoid perforation; adjust port angle based on gallbladder height and anatomy.
Placing the port too low flattens the approach and worsens control; position the port higher for a better upward angle.
Lower arm when handling the tool.
Lift gallbladder up.
Avoid grabbing fat.
Avoid putting instrument tips into the middle of the gallbladder.
Gentle sweep to clean fat.
When lifting the gallbladder, grasp close to the dissection plane; pulling from too far away tears fatty tissue, causing bleeding and poor visibility.
Take a small, accurate grasp on the true edge of the plane ('lip'), not surrounding fat; use both hands to apply opposing tension.
Hook then pull to left to dissect.
Regrab the fat to create a better angle.
Grab closer to the target.
Fan the fat laterally for a better view of the hole.
The shape and color of gallbladder show chronic inflammation.
Grab closer.
The lip is fat and can be grabbed.
How to coordinate two hands.
Rotate camera so that instruments are not blocking the view.
Lifting the gallbladder too hard collapses the plane; ease off tension so tissue unfolds naturally.
If you can't see a structure clearly, stop dissecting. Three options: adjust camera/retraction, push other structures away, or move the tissue.
Leah suggests the next step.
Leah pointed out the left hand is not doing well.
Open the graspers more to grab more gallbladder.
Open grasper more, push in, grab, and lift to create better view.
A stable, slightly oblique camera angle gives better 3D cues. Avoid steep downward views that distort relationships in Calot's triangle. Camera and instrument angles should complement each other.
Move away liver for better view.
Analyzing the anatomy.
Grab the gallbladder and look at what is behind.
The surgeon can't fully see the anatomy, so they reason where it should be and start with a shallow, safe incision in the visible area to expose the plane gradually.
Senior surgeons discuss which plane to start dissecting.
Two options for dissection: thinning or layer by layer.
Actions.
Hook cautery technique: gentle sweeping to separate tissue and skeletonize duct or artery.
Slow down and read anatomy carefully. Dissect along visible gallbladder edge in known safe zone.
What looks like a nerve is likely connective tissue. Stay shallow and dissect along peritoneum.
Need to angle the tool up.
Push in to make dissection.
Sweep to rip.
Push gently to open plane and continue freeing tissue toward target base.
Anatomy recognition: beyond it lies liver.
Push in.
Push in then turn.
Hook near gallbladder-liver interface can catch wrong structure; stay in correct plane.
Use camera to visualize how left-hand instrument shapes field; pulling creates dissection space.
Regrab at lower place.
Recognizing artery.
Recognize when left-hand tool obstructs view or movement; adjust to avoid stressing liver.
Hook heel.
No dig, stay on surface.
Coordinate between two hands.
When tissue is translucent and converges like a faucet, it’s a safe zone—sweep to expose base.
Too deep now, don’t go up.
If dissecting near vessel, don't cross halfway or pull too hard while cauterizing.
Avoid energy activation while touching gallbladder; avoid excessive traction to let small vessels coagulate.
Gentle sweeping.
Recognize a true dissection plane.
Keep dissecting with Marilyn.
Spread tension to avoid bleeding.
Take peritoneal tissue off.
When peritoneum is tented by a band, an artery lies beneath; peel gently to expose safely.
Grab fat to skeletonize the ductal structures.
Use the 'roll' grasping technique.
Touch the structure to figure out what it is.
Safe exploration and spatial judgment.
The white tissue is the safe spot for dissection.
Touch and confirm nothing is there; continue pushing the dissector to make the dissection.
Push harder.
Big sweep at the clip site.
Fat down; duct coming into view.
Next move: keep cleaning fat.
Resident dissected at the wrong place.
Get more tissue and be more aggressive.
Risk in proceeding because the structure is not clear.
Duct shape is clear; clean the surrounding fat.
Dissection based on recognizing the artery—keep that in mind.
Switch to skeletonize the artery.
Rotate tool slightly downward so both jaws/tips contact tissue for friction and effective dissection.
Bleeding noted; cause uncertain.
Anatomy is confusing—recognizing base vs. gallbladder.
Dissect at a higher position.

Brian suggests skeletonizing the duct next.
Two holes in the fat; start with the upper one.
Sequence: push in, rotate, sweep.

The node was vascular, causing bleeding.
Spread on both sides of the cystic artery with Maryland; fully expose its length to confirm you're not at the base.
Keep instrument perpendicular to vessel/duct axis; rotate or curl to match orientation.

If structure unknown, pull with tool to check.
For unknown structures, grab gently.
Anatomy is confusing—nothing or vessel?

After dissecting the back of the gallbladder, unknown structure seen connected to gallbladder.
Slide down clips when applying.
Move clips up and visualize clip tips.
If a clip is misoriented, remove and reload it.
A 30° instrument rotation changes the approach angle by ~60°, misaligning the clip.
When the cystic duct is short, avoid dissecting too much to lengthen it; instead, clip slightly higher for a secure seal.
Keep tool parallel, let heel glide off tissue, and use minimal pressure for precise, safe dissection.
Surgeon releases traction before applying energy to avoid tearing; cauterizes small vessel carefully, anticipating tension change to maintain control.
Checks that the sealed stump is secure and dry before removing ports.
Checks for bleeding by moving the camera back and forth.
Withdraws scope to inspect each port site; instruments removed in sequence.
